briefOverview: A revelation to Sidney Gilbert outlining his ecclesiastical and temporal assignments, with a call to forsake the world and endure to the end.
summary: The Lord responds to Sidney Gilbert’s request for direction about his calling, commanding him to forsake the world. He is to be ordained an elder to preach faith, repentance, remission of sins, and the reception of the Holy Spirit by laying on of hands. He is also appointed to act as an agent for the church in a place designated by the bishop. Gilbert is instructed to travel with Joseph Smith Jr. and Sidney Rigdon. The Lord notes these as his first ordinances, promising further instruction according to his labor. The revelation concludes with the principle that salvation comes to those who endure to the end.
externalContext: This revelation dates to 1831 during rapid organization in the early Latter-day Saint movement, centered in Ohio with an emerging focus on Missouri. Edward Partridge had been appointed as the first bishop, overseeing temporal affairs, including land and resources. Sidney Gilbert, a merchant associated with the Gilbert & Whitney store, was well positioned to serve as a church “agent,” a role that involved purchasing, managing, and distributing goods on behalf of the bishop. Around this time, leaders traveled from Ohio to Missouri in response to earlier instructions designating Missouri as a gathering place.
externalReferences: The directive to preach repentance, remission of sins, and to administer the Holy Spirit by laying on of hands aligns with New Testament patterns (Acts 2:38; Acts 8:17; Hebrews 6:2). The charge to endure to the end echoes Jesus’ teaching (Matthew 24:13) and similar early Latter-day Saint revelations (Doctrine and Covenants 14:7). The instruction for Gilbert to journey with Joseph Smith and Sidney Rigdon connects to broader calls for leaders to travel to Missouri (Doctrine and Covenants 52). Gilbert’s role as church “agent” is further detailed later with Missouri assignments (Doctrine and Covenants 57:6–10).
practicalQuestions: What does it mean for me to ‘forsake the world’ in my current circumstances?
How can I prepare to teach faith, repentance, and the gift of the Holy Spirit with clarity and integrity?
In what ways can professional skills be consecrated to serve the community’s needs, as with acting as an ‘agent’ for the church?
How do I cultivate endurance so that I remain faithful over time, not just at the outset of a calling?
Am I willing to follow assignments that involve travel or collaboration with leaders, trusting further guidance will come as I labor?
uncertainAreas: The precise meaning of “calling and election” here may refer broadly to Gilbert’s church assignments rather than later doctrinal nuances; the specific content of the “first ordinances” beyond ordination is not fully itemized; and the location and duties attached to being an “agent” are not detailed in this chapter but clarified elsewhere.
